title: In-situ Observation of Formation Mechanism of Infinite-layer Iron Oxide
content: Infinite-layer transition metal oxides with two-dimensional (2-D) oxygen coordination exhibit intriguing magnetic properties due to strong in-plane orbital hybridization [1][2][3]. Nevertheless, with the exception of the limited instances observed in cuprite, the synthesis of this metastable phase has predominantly been restricted to the kinetically controlled hydride reduction of oxygen-rich phases with three-dimensional (3-D) polygonal oxygen coordination. Considering the relative instability compared to its thermodynamically stable end phases through decomposition, capturing the rapid transformation to metastable infinite-layer phase during reduction with atomic resolution presents a challenge.
